Greetings Telesilla - devout servant of the Muses and celebrated defender of Argos. Blessed with the ability to weave words as well as Ariadne could work a loom, it is up to you to lead your fellow Argives through tragedy and triumph. Whether that means commanding a defense from the city walls or raising the spirits of your countrymen through your sun-loving songs, it is certain that your people are in good hands either way.
The Defense of Argos

Telesilla
Poet and Defender of Argos
Telesilla was an ancient Argive poet known for both her poetry and her leadership in the defense of the city of Argos against a Spartan attack.

Little is known about Telesilla's life, with much of what we knowing coming from other writers who lived long after her. Pausanias writes that Telesilla was sickly, so she consulted the Pythia at the Oracle of Delphi. The Pythia told her to "serve the Muses" and thus Telsilla's career as a poet began. Almost none of her work remains extant, but she is known nonetheless as a renowned lyric poet, responsible for the invention of the metrical innovation known as the Telesillian Meter.

In the year 494 BCE, King Cleomenes of Sparta invaded Argolis. It is said that the Spartans killed many of the Argive hoplites at the Battle of Sepeia and the rest at the sanctuary of Argus outside the city, leaving Argos defenseless. As the Spartans approached the city, Telesilla rallied the Argive women and the remaining men of the city (slaves, farmers, or rural populace, depending on the interpretation) to Argos's walls. She oversaw the collection and distribution of arms to the defenders, and encouraged them to stand fast in the face of the intimidating Spartan army. The display of force was a success - depending on the source, the Spartans either retreated without a battle or after taking heavy losses.

What happened to Telesilla after the defense of Argos, unfortunately, is a mystery. The Argive population - spared the ignonimity of defeat - was grateful for Telesilla's leadership; they erected a statue in front of the Temple of Aphrodite depicting a woman holding a helmet in her hands and with books at her feet, said to honor the leadership of Telesilla and the other Argive women for their part in saving Argos from defeat at the hands of the Spartans. It was also said that, after the battle, the Argive women refused to go back to being subservient to the men of the city, with the social chaos possibly serving as the source of the festival of the Hybristica, in which wives would dress as men and berate their husbands.

What is known for certain is that Telesilla's contributions were not forgotten. Her work is recorded as being referenced as late as the second century CE and she was held up as a model of civic virtue for centuries after her death, proving that her achievements were among thsoe that would stand the test of time.

Telesilla has a unique ability to translate defensive structures into Great People production and then channel that cultural output into military strength. You'll need to challenge her on both fronts to be successful against her.

As Telesilla, generating Great People should be your primary focus, particularly Great Writers. Fill up your Great Work Slots in peace time, but when your cities can no longer hold any more, send your Great Writers and Musicians off to inspire your troops to conquer some more room. Don't forget to build up your defenses back home as well - they'll help keep you safe and also add to your army of poets and wordsmiths to keep up the pressure on your rivals!
Welcome to Argos, traveller. I am Telesilla, a humble poet and citizen of this great city. May the Muses look kindly on our meeting this day.
Won't you come and visit one of the towns of Argolis? They may not be as bustling as some of our neighbors', but what they lack in size they make up for in charm.
How kind! I'm sure this will be the spark for a new poem - should the Muses grant me their inspiration of course!
Hmm... Our globe here - symbol of the great Muse Ourania - seems to not show your capital. Let's rectify this error, shall we? We can update yours accordingly as well if you'd like...
Oh, you've arrived just as I've put the finishing touches on my latest poem. Care to listen?
Please state your business - I have other matters to attend to.
On behalf of Argos, I accept your delegation. We shall arrange a festival in honor of their arrival.
The gates of Argos are closed to outsiders at this time.

May I offer you a few small tokens of my goodwill? I have arranged to have some of Argolis's finest olives, melons, oranges sent to you - as well as an ornate shield like the ones our Hoplites wield. Did you know that its grip was designed here in Argos? It's true!
Your men will be treated as guests here in Argos, you have my promise.
I must decline - we cannot play host to your troops at this time.
Our brave troops have received their orders and request to pass through your lands. Will you agree to this?
Outstanding! I, of course, accept - praise the Muses!
Oh! I'm sorry, it's just that I'm... really busy - you know - with... the poems... So many poems...
The Muses provide inspiration to our world's finest minds, and you have in turn inspired in me feelings of amiability. I would most honored to be able to call you a friend.
Oh, thank the Muses! How wonderful!
Oh, I see. Well, perhaps I was too hasty in my offer...

Did you know that I invented the word 'philhelias'? It means 'sun-loving': two words united to produce a new creation with special meaning; just imagine what our nations could create if united with such purpose. What say you?
My, my! Your civilization seems to overflow with talented minds. Clearly you have been blessed by the Muses themselves!
Oh dear, it seems that your civilization is as bereft of genius as the desert is of rain. What a pity that your people do not receive the divine inspiration of the Muses...
I may not have the eyes of Argos Panoptes, but even I can see the provocations of your troops. Send them away at once.
Agreed.
That is not possible.
Your base language is frankly incomprehensible to me, but I gather that you mean to intimidate me? Ha! You'll have to do better than that!
I have pledged my life to serve the Muses - your destruction, dismissal, and denial of their work can no longer be ignored (Denounces You).

If you were a more learned person, I would have said that this could have been avoided, but I know that violence is all that someone like you is capable of. To arms, fellow Argives! Our city shall not fall!
Are you perchance familiar with Melpomene? No? Allow me to educate you: she is the Muse of Tragedy, and that is surely what awaits your civilization after Argos is through with you.
Wonderful - the flower of inspiration does not grow well in the unforgiving season of war.
Begging for clemency will not garner you mention in the annals of history. Clio rewards valor and you offer not but cowardice!
War is such an upleasant matter is it not? What say we put this all behind us?
Despite my best efforts, Argos has fallen - it's temples and monuments in ruins. Who will serve the Muses now that I am gone? I weep for a world without their inspiration! Hardly a world at all...
